body.p: One of the stages of red blood cell production is called the reticulocyte, so named because these cells contain ribosomal RNA strands that when stained look like reticular fibers. Reticulocytes are those cells recently released by the bone marrow and only circulate for about 24 hours before becoming mature RBCs. Normally about 1% of circulating RBCs are reticulocytes.
In the hours and days after donating blood, what would you expect to happen to both your erythropoietin levels and your reticulocyte count?

multiple_choice.choice: Erythropoeitin will increase and reticulocyte count will decrease.
Erythropoeitin will decrease and reticulocyte count will increase.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Blood donation can cause your total volume of RBCs to fall by up to 10%. This would stimulate changes in erythropoietin and reticulocyte count, but not in the directions chosen.

Correct. Blood donation can cause your total volume of RBCs to fall by up to 10%. This would stimulate an increase in erythropoietin, which would stimulate your bone marrow to increase production of RBCs, causing the release of more reticulocytes.
Incorrect. Blood donation can cause your total volume of RBCs to fall by up to 10%. This would stimulate an increase in erythropoietin but not a decrease in reticulocyte count.
Incorrect. Blood donation can cause your total volume of RBCs to fall by up to 10%. This would stimulate an increase in erythropoietin.

part.hint: After donating blood the body would like to rapidly replace the lost cells.
